instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
[B]<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>[/B] keeps blowing up before diode <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and reaching pp3v42.

Any idea why?

Its been trolling me for some time now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
"reaching pp3v42"
Who?
I don't really understand what you mean...

Check all 4.7uF (<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>-97) placed after <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
Now <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> is probably shorted too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR> is shorted to ground. I detached the CAP. the short is still there inside the board it seems under the pad... How do I go about to solve that issue? drill a hole in the board through it?



(pp3v42.. forget that, i was just mumbling.)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Dig a bit in the board, until short is gone.
You can also try to cut off the trace and bypass "on air" that point, if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
hi 2informaticos, sorry late reply, was busy with my other businesses.. 

I dig the bottom, there is no continuity now.. But the resistor 10 ohm, still exploded after putting a new one... So strange. what could cause that to happen.. ? The trace is inside the board to the other side.. wont be possible to cut off the trace, unless u have a great idea how to? 

I could add jumpers from that cap to the other points its should connect to and see what happens. What do u suggest?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
You can discard one cap.
Be sure to have continuity for all others and no short, or low value to ground.
